**The New Creation Called, Counted, and Built**

As Israel arrived at Mount Sinai, we too, in our journey toward the eternal home, have arrived at our own “Sinai moment.” This is not a place on a map for us, but a spiritual reality. Sinai is the place where God meets His people, makes covenant, reveals holiness, and begins to form them with order.
Even the name carries a message. Sinai is connected with a thorny place, and the same word family is used for the thorn-bush where the burning bush appeared in Exodus 3. Moses saw fire in the bush, yet the bush was not consumed (Exodus 3:2). That scene already teaches something about God’s ways: God’s presence is holy fire, yet He can dwell in what is weak and ordinary without destroying it. The thorn-bush reminds us that God often meets His people in places that are not comfortable, not smooth, and not easy-yet His glory shines there.

Sinai is tightly tied to covenant. At Sinai, God made Israel a covenant nation. He declared them His special possession and called them “a kingdom of priests, and an holy nation” (Exodus 19:5-6). This was Israel’s national birth moment. They were not only rescued from Egypt; they were formed for God. Sinai is also where God revealed His holiness and His law. The Ten Commandments were given in Exodus 20, and the wider covenant instructions showed what it looks like to live with a holy God dwelling in the middle of the camp. This teaches a strong truth: God is near, but God is not casual. Nearness is not permission to be careless. Nearness is a call to reverence.

Sinai also established mediated access to God. The mountain shook, there was fire, there was thick cloud, there was a trumpet blast, and the people feared to approach (Exodus 19:16-20). They even said to Moses, “Speak thou with us… but let not God speak with us, lest we die” (Exodus 20:19). That moment planted a truth deep in the mind of Israel: sinful humans need a mediator to stand between God and man. Moses acted as mediator there, going up and coming down, receiving God’s words and bringing them to the people.
This is not removed in the New Testament. It is fulfilled. Scripture says,
“There is one God, and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus” (1 Timothy 2:5). We do not come to God by our goodness. We come through the Mediator God appointed.

Sinai also gave the pattern for worship and God’s dwelling. Right after Sinai, God gave the blueprint for the tabernacle and priesthood (Exodus 25-31).
So Sinai is not only “rules.” Sinai also declares, “God wants to dwell among us.” This is why Numbers opens with these words: “YAHWEH spoke to Moses. The tabernacle is standing. God’s presence is in the midst. And now God begins to organize His people.

This is where the new creation begins to see itself in the mirror of Israel. Hebrews tells us that we have not come to the shaking mountain in fear, but to something greater. “Ye are come unto mount Zion, and unto the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem… and to Jesus the mediator of the new covenant” (Hebrews 12:22-24). Sinai shows holiness and distance. Zion shows access and joy through Christ. Yet the same chapter warns us not to refuse the One who speaks from heaven (Hebrews 12:25). This means the new creation has boldness, but not carelessness. We have confidence, but not casual living. We have joyful gathering, but still holy fear.

Now we must notice a pattern that appears both at Sinai and at the start of Numbers. The first action is not marching, not fighting, not building. The first action is that God speaks. “YAHWEH spoke…” (Numbers 1:1). In the same way, new creation begins when God’s word comes with authority into the heart. “Faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God” (Romans 10:17). We do not become new by self-improvement. We become new by God’s living word. Scripture also says we are “born again… by the word of God, which liveth and abideth for ever” (1 Peter 1:23). So the voice of God is not only instruction; it is life-giving power. When God speaks, light comes into darkness. When God speaks, faith is awakened. When God speaks, a people are formed.

Then the text says God spoke “in the wilderness.” Wilderness means no natural supply. It is a place where the old world cannot sustain the new life.
This matches our walk. God trains dependence. Israel got manna.
Israel got water from the rock. We receive daily strength from Christ. Jesus said, “I am the bread of life” (John 6:35). Paul heard Yahweh say, “My grace is sufficient for thee” (2 Corinthians 12:9). Even Jesus was led into the wilderness and overcame there by the Word of God (Matthew 4:1-4). This teaches us that wilderness seasons are not only punishment. Many times, wilderness is training. God removes natural supports so that His people learn spiritual dependence.

Now we must look again at the thorns. Sinai points to the thorn-bush. And we also remember Christ wore a crown of thorns (Matthew 27:29). This is not a small connection. The covenant we have is purchased through suffering.
We have come to God through the thorns of Christ. At Sinai, Israel’s birth moment was the covenant at the mountain. For the church, the birth moment is connected to Christ’s death and resurrection, and the Spirit being poured out. On the day of Pentecost, the church was formed openly as a Spirit-filled people (Acts 2:1-4). And the calling given to Israel “a kingdom of priests and a holy nation”- is now spoken over the new creation. Peter writes to us, “Ye are a chosen generation, a royal priesthood, an holy nation” (1 Peter 2:9).
Through the blood of Christ, God has made a covenant people again, not by tribe and land, but by faith and Spirit.

Just as Moses stood as mediator for Israel, today Christ is our mediator. Hebrews says He is the mediator of the new covenant (Hebrews 9:15; 12:24). And just as Sinai led to the tabernacle blueprint, Christ gives the pattern for God’s dwelling today. The tabernacle is no longer cloth and boards.
The tabernacle is God’s people. Scripture says we are “living stones” being built into a spiritual house (1 Peter 2:5). Paul says believers are “builded together for an habitation of God through the Spirit” (Ephesians 2:22). So we are not only forgiven individuals. We are a dwelling place being constructed.
God is building a house where He will dwell.

After calling and covenant comes order. In Numbers 1, God calls the tribes, except Levi, to be counted for war. This is one of the strongest parallels for the church. God counts warriors because the journey to inheritance includes conflict. For Israel, the conflict was physical. For believers, the conflict is spiritual. “We wrestle not against flesh and blood” (Ephesians 6:12). “The weapons of our warfare are not carnal” (2 Corinthians 10:4). Yet the warfare is real. This is why Scripture calls us to be soldiers. Paul says, “Endure hardness, as a good soldier of Jesus Christ” (2 Timothy 2:3). He also says, “No man that warreth entangleth himself with the affairs of this life; that he may please him who hath chosen him to be a soldier” (2 Timothy 2:4). Peter adds that we should not be surprised by fiery trials, because these trials test faith (1 Peter 4:12).
So when God counts warriors, He is teaching readiness. He is forming a people who can stand, pray, resist the devil, flee from passions and remain faithful.

This is why the armor of God is given to the church. We are told to be strong in Yahweh, to put on the whole armor, and to stand against the devil’s schemes (Ephesians 6:10-18). We are told to resist the devil and he will flee (James 4:7). We are told to fight the good fight of faith (1 Timothy 6:12). The church is not a sleeping camp. It is an army under the God’s command, fighting with truth, righteousness, faith, prayer, and the Word.

Now the age limit in Numbers is twenty years and upward. For Israel, the text connects it clearly to war readiness and public obligation (Numbers 1:3). Spiritually, “twenty” becomes a sign of responsibility, public identification, and structured holiness. The Torah itself shows this threshold in other places.
In Exodus, those “twenty years old and upward” were required to give the half-shekel offering connected to the service of the tabernacle (Exodus 30:14–16). This shows that twenty is connected to public duty and contribution to God’s dwelling. In Leviticus 27, the valuation system uses “twenty” as a formal value marker for dedication (Leviticus 27:5). The sanctuary shekel itself is connected to “twenty gerahs” as an official measure (Exodus 30:13), showing that twenty is also tied to holy measurement and standard. Even in tabernacle structure, there are “twenty boards” on a side (Exodus 26:18, 20), showing order, stability, and framework. And later, Solomon’s inner sanctuary is measured twenty by twenty by twenty cubits, a perfect cube (1 Kings 6:20), showing the geometry of holiness and the pattern of God’s most holy place.

When we bring these verses together, the spiritual picture becomes clearer.
God is selecting a people who will be responsible in His service, public in their identity, generous in their offering, strong as part of His structure, and holy in their pattern, a perfect cube. This is how God is selecting us. First, we show ourselves openly as belonging to God. Baptism becomes the public mark of entering Christ. “So many of us as were baptized into Jesus Christ were baptized into his death… that we should walk in newness of life” (Romans 6:3-4). This is not only an outward sign. It is a covenant identification.

Second, we are called to offer ourselves. Just as Israel gave the half-shekel for tabernacle service, we give ourselves as living sacrifices. “Present your bodies a living sacrifice” (Romans 12:1). The new creation does not offer coins to purchase favor; the new creation offers life because it has received mercy.
Our time, strength, decisions, desires, and plans are placed on God’s altar.

Third, we are called to become part of God’s structure. The tabernacle boards held the dwelling together. In the same way, we are living stones being built together. We are not isolated believers floating alone. We are joined. We are fitly framed together. “In whom all the building fitly framed together groweth unto an holy temple in the Yahweh” (Ephesians 2:21). This means we must accept being shaped, corrected, aligned, and joined. A stone that refuses shaping cannot fit into the house. A soldier that refuses discipline cannot stand in battle.

Fourth, we are called to holiness that matches God’s most holy pattern.
The perfect cube of the inner sanctuary reminds us that God’s goal is not only forgiveness, but holiness. “Be ye holy; for I am holy” (1 Peter 1:16). And we are being transformed into the image of Christ (Romans 8:29). This is not instant perfection, but it is a real journey of change. God is building a dwelling, and His dwelling must reflect His nature.

So in these first few verses, we see a complete design. Sinai shows covenant and holiness. The wilderness shows dependence and training. The tabernacle shows God dwelling among His people. The census shows readiness for warfare.
The age threshold shows responsibility and structure. And through it all, the first action remains the same: God speaks. If we will be the new creation God desires, we must be a people who listen, a people who obey, a people who are ordered, and a people who are ready for spiritual war.

There is one more design hidden here from the record of creation itself, where God speaks, order forms, a dwelling place is prepared, and a people are assigned their place. This pattern is deeper than we have opened today. If God permits, we will study that tomorrow, in Christ name Amen.
